TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:  Mostly in sinus rhythm with prolonged PR interval,
   frequent PACs and rare PVCs.  Long run of symptomatic VT at 22:23 on
   tele which converted back to SR w/o ICD firing.  5 beats of NSVT at
   2300.  Right groin hematoma stable.  On heparin gtt and Coumadin.  He
   is very anxious and is concerned that he will go back into VT and get
   shocked.  He had difficulty sleeping and required Ambien, Ativan, and
   clonazepam.
   Allergies:
   Monosodium Glutamate
   Palpitations;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:
   Heparin Sodium - 1,300 units/hour
   Lidocaine - 2 mg/min

   Physical Examination
   GENERAL: Pleasant gentleman in NAD, appears comfortable. Oriented x3.
   Mood, affect appropriate.
   HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no
   pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
   NECK: Supple with JVP of 5 cm.
   CARDIAC: PMI displaced laterally, located in 5th intercostal space. S1
   & S2 irregular with a blowing systolic murmur heard best at apex. No
   thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were
   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or
   rhonchi.
   ABDOMEN: Soft, NT/ND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by
   palpation. No abdominial bruits.
   EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. Right thigh hematoma at cath site with borders
   demarcated in marker, no hematoma or bruit of left thigh.
   SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.

   Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP/PT by Doppler
   Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP/PT by Doppler

        [image002.jpg]
                             [**2118-8-31**]  04:30 AM
   WBC

   Hct
   36.5
   Plt
   272
   Cr
   1.1
   Glucose
   107
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:20.7/62.0/1.9, Ca++:8.8 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7
   mg/dL, PO4:3.9 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of some but not all foci
   requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, now on lidocaine
   ggt and amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has [**Month/Year (2) 9226**] and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of some but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT which broke on its own without
   defibrillation
   - Heparin drip with bridge to Coumadin
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - EP today?
   .
   # MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 9226**]: Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral
   valve replacement
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Coumadin restarted after EPS
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - recheck Cr in AM
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna PRN
   -Famotidine
   CODE: Full
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 31**] [**Known lastname 9222**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9227**]; [**Name (NI) 815**] [**Name (NI) 9228**] (Girlfriend)
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9229**]
   DISPO: CCU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Cardiac diet
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2118-8-30**] 06:33 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2118-8-30**] 06:34 PM
   22 Gauge - [**2118-8-30**] 06:35 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2118-8-31**] 02:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin IV, Coumadin
   Stress ulcer:  famotidine
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: patient and son [**Name (NI) 31**]
   [**Name (NI) 36**] status: Full code
   Disposition: CCU

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital due to repeated episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) resulting in multiple ICD firings. He had an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was started on lidocaine and amiodarone. The patient's current vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 59-77 beats per minute, blood pressure of 116/63-127/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. He is on heparin and Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis and has a right groin hematoma that is stable.

The patient has a history of NSVT, and his current arrhythmia is likely caused by two distinct morphologies, one coming from the lateral ventricle and one from the mitral valve area. He had a run of symptomatic sustained VT that broke on its own without defibrillation. The patient is currently on lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID.

Potential medical complications:

1. Recurrence of ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of NSVT and the presence of two distinct morphologies of arrhythmia suggest a high risk of recurrence.
2. Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient's current arrhythmia is likely to continue, and the risk of cardiac arrest is high.
3. Thromboembolic events: The patient is on heparin and Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis, but the risk of thromboembolic events is still present.
4. Renal failure: The patient's current Cr level of 1.1 mg/dL and urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6, indicating pre-renal failure likely due to volume depletion.
5. Depression and anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety is a concern, and his current symptoms of anxiety and insomnia are a potential complication.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated, and the risk of hypertension-related complications is present.
7. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease and may require further management.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID to control the patient's arrhythmia.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs closely, particularly his heart rate and blood pressure.
3. Continue heparin and Coumadin for DVT prophylaxis.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely, and consider adjusting his fluid management and electrolyte levels as needed.
5. Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral valve replacement.
6. Continue antidepressant medication and consider increasing the dosage if necessary.
7. Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia.
8. Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID to manage the patient's hypertension.
9. Continue Simvastatin to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia.
10. Monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust his insulin regimen as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and was recently treated with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) and underwent an electrophysiology study (EPS) with successful ablation of some but not all foci. The patient has been experiencing VT episodes, which have resulted in multiple ICD firings, and is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone infusions.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 35.7°C (96.3°F)
* Heart rate: 59 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 116/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

The patient's physical examination is notable for a pleasant gentleman in no acute distress, oriented x3, with a supple neck and no jugular venous distension. Cardiac examination reveals a displaced point of maximal impulse (PMI) laterally, with an irregular heart rhythm and a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 16 mg/dL
* Sodium: 134 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.4 mEq/L
* Chloride: 19 mEq/L
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Ventricular tachycardia
* Atrial fibrillation
* Hyperlipidemia
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
* Acute renal failure
* Depression/anxiety

The patient is currently receiving the following medications:

* Lidocaine infusion
* Amiodarone infusion
* Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
* Simvastatin
* Coumadin
* Effexor 75mg PO Daily
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn Sleep

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions and medications include:

* Arrhythmia recurrences
* Cardiac tamponade
* Myocardial infarction
* Stroke
* Renal failure progression
* Respiratory failure
* Infection
* Bleeding complications from anticoagulation therapy

Given the patient's complex medical conditions and treatment plan, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to ensure that he receives optimal care and to prevent potential complications.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T= 35.7°C, HR= 59 bpm, BP= 116/63 mmHg, RR= 16 breaths per minute, SpO2= 96%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus bradycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs) and rare premature ventricular contractions (PVCs)
* Cardiac examination: PMI displaced laterally, S1 and S2 irregular with a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex
* Respiratory examination: Unlabored respiration with no accessory muscle use
* Abdominal examination: Soft, non-tender abdomen with no palpable masses or bruits
* Extremities: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Complete blood count: WBC= 11.7 K/uL, Hct= 36.5%, Platelet count= 272 K/uL
* Blood chemistry: Sodium= 134 mEq/L, Potassium= 4.4 mEq/L, Creatinine= 1.1 mg/dL, Glucose= 107 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: Calcium= 8.8 mg/dL, Magnesium= 1.7 mg/dL, Phosphorus= 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical history includes a history of VT, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and mitral valve prolapse (MVP). He has also undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure and has been treated with lidocaine and amiodarone for his VT.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of VT and the presence of frequent PACs and PVCs suggest that he may be at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias.
* Cardiac failure: The patient's history of MVP and the presence of a blowing systolic murmur suggest that he may be at risk for cardiac failure.
* Respiratory complications: The patient's history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and the presence of chronic bronchitis suggest that he may be at risk for respiratory complications.
* Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of peptic ulcer disease and the presence of chronic gastritis suggest that he may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications.
* Neurological complications: The patient's history of hypertension and the presence of chronic kidney disease suggest that he may be at risk for neurological complications.

Based on the patient's condition and medical history, it is recommended that he continue to receive treatment with lidocaine and amiodarone for his VT, and that he be monitored closely for any signs of cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, respiratory complications, gastrointestinal complications, or neurological complications.

   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has [**Month/Year (2) 9226**] and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of some but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT which broke on its own without
   defibrillation
   - Heparin drip with bridge to Coumadin
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   - EP today?
   .
   # MR [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 9226**]: Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral
   valve replacement
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Continue Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Coumadin restarted after EPS
   - consider ECHO tomorrow
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - recheck Cr in AM
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and is currently admitted to the ICU due to recurrent episodes of VT resulting in multiple ICD firings. He was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and initiation of sotalol to control his heart rate.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.4°C (99.4°F)
* Heart rate: 59-77 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 116/63-127/70 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 16-23 inspirations per minute (ipm)
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* SpO2: 96%

The patient has a history of NSVT, sustained VT episodes, and has undergone multiple defibrillations. He has been started on lidocaine and amiodarone to control his arrhythmia.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Sinus bradycardia
* Prolonged PR interval
* Frequent premature atrial contractions (PACs) and rare premature ventricular contractions (PVCs)
* No signs of cardiac failure or pulmonary congestion
* No evidence of coronary artery disease

The patient's medications include:

* Lidocaine drip at 2mg/min
* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
* Coumadin
* Heparin drip with bridge to Coumadin

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Recurrent VT episodes
* ICD firing
* Cardiac failure
* Pulmonary edema
* Arrhythmia-related complications (e.g., atrial fibrillation, flutter)
* Renal failure (due to arrhythmia-related hypotension and decreased cardiac output)
* Depression and anxiety (due to the patient's underlying condition and medication regimen)

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is recommended to:

* Continue monitoring the patient's cardiac rhythm and vital signs
* Adjust the patient's medication regimen as needed to control his arrhythmia and prevent complications
* Consider consulting cardiothoracic surgery for mitral valve replacement
* Obtain a 12-lead EKG if the patient goes back into VT
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly
* Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization to prevent thrombotic complications
* Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medication regimen as needed to manage his depression and anxiety.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing multiple episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and having an unsuccessful ablation procedure. He has a history of non-sustained VT and has been on lidocaine and amiodarone to control his heart rhythm. The patient's current medications include lidocaine, amiodarone, and metoprolol. He has also been prescribed aspirin, simvastatin, and famotidine for prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and hyperlipidemia, respectively.

The patient's physical examination is stable, with a regular sinus rhythm and a blood pressure of 116/63 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% on a nasal cannula. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 11.7 K/uL, a hemoglobin level of 12.8 g/dL, and a platelet count of 272 K/uL. His creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 19 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a history of atrial fibrillation. He has also had a recent episode of acute renal failure, which is likely related to his arrhythmia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the recent episode of symptomatic VT at 22:23 on tele, which converted back to sinus rhythm without ICD firing, suggests that VT may continue to be a concern.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his BUN level is high, indicating that he may be at risk for further renal damage.
3. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's rate-controlled atrial fibrillation may persist, and he may require further treatment to control his heart rhythm.
4. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's high cholesterol levels may increase his risk for cardiovascular events.
5. Depression/anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may exacerbate his symptoms and affect his quality of life.
6. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and lack of signs of heart failure suggest that he may be at risk for further cardiac complications.
7. Mitral valve disease: The patient's mitral valve disease may require further evaluation and treatment to prevent further cardiac complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lidocaine and amiodarone to control the patient's heart rhythm.
2. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and BUN level to assess for further renal damage.
3. Consider further treatment for the patient's atrial fibrillation, such as cardioversion or anticoagulation therapy.
4. Monitor the patient's lipids and consider starting aspirin to reduce his risk of cardiovascular events.
5. Continue depression and anxiety treatment, such as Effexor and Clonazepam, and consider starting a sleep aid like Ambien.
6. Consider referring the patient to a cardiologist or cardiothoracic surgeon for further evaluation and treatment of his mitral valve disease and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure. He is currently on lidocaine drip and amiodarone, and is being treated for atrial fibrillation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 37.4°C, Heart rate 59 bpm, Blood pressure 116/63 mmHg, Respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, Oxygen saturation 96%.
* Physical examination: The patient is pleasant and appears comfortable, with a displaced PMI, a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex, and no thrills, lifts, S3, or S4.
* Laboratory results: The patient's WBC count is 11.7 K/uL, Hct is 36.5%, Plt is 272 K/uL, Cr is 1.1 mg/dL, Glucose is 107 mg/dL, and other lab results are within normal limits.

The patient's medical history includes:

* Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a 1-28 year history of NSVT with sustained VT episodes and is s/p ICD placement.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient has rate-controlled atrial fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip.
* Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of coronary artery disease.
* Hypertropic cardiomyopathy: The patient has preserved EF= 55-60% and no signs of failure.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's Cr was 1.4 at OSH, 1.1 at admission, and 1.2 on [**8-30**], and the etiology is likely due to arrhythmia.

The patient's current medications include:

* Lidocaine drip
* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 50mg PO BID
* Simvastatin
* Coumadin
* Heparin drip
* Famotidine
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Effexor 75mg PO Daily
* Ambien prn Sleep

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the presence of NSVT on telemetry suggest a high risk of recurrent VT, which could lead to cardiac arrest or death.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's rate-controlled atrial fibrillation may progress to atrial flutter or atrial tachycardia, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's pre-renal failure and the presence of hyperkalemia may worsen his renal function, leading to further kidney damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Depression/anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may worsen during his hospitalization, leading to decreased quality of life and increased risk of complications.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and treatment for his arrhythmias, as well as ongoing management of his acute renal failure and depression/anxiety. Further consultation with cardiothoracic surgery for mitral valve replacement may be necessary to address the patient's underlying cardiac condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital due to repeated episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and multiple ICD firings. He has a history of non-sustained VT and has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure. The patient was started on lidocaine and amiodarone to control his arrhythmia, but he continued to experience symptomatic sustained VT episodes. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed two distinct morphologies of his arrhythmia, likely originating from the lateral ventricle and the mitral valve area.

The patient's physical examination is notable for a displaced PMI, irregular S1 and S2 heart sounds, and a blowing systolic murmur at the apex. His lung examination is clear, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

Laboratory results show anemia, with a hematocrit of 33%. The patient's creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL, and his potassium level is 4.1 mEq/L. His magnesium level is 2.1 mg/dL, and his phosphate level is 3.3 mg/dL.

The patient's medications include lidocaine, amiodarone, metoprolol, and coumadin. He is also taking aspirin, simvastatin, and Effexor.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and multiple ICD firings increase his risk of future episodes. The patient's ECG showed two distinct morphologies of his arrhythmia, which may indicate a higher risk of VT recurrence.
2. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit level of 33% indicates significant anemia. This may be due to hemodilution, and the patient's hemoglobin level should be monitored closely.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his urine output should be closely monitored. The etiology of his acute renal failure is likely due to arrhythmia, and the patient should be monitored for signs of worsening renal function.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is elevated, and his blood pressure should be closely monitored to prevent complications.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia, which may increase his risk of cardiovascular disease.
6. Depression/anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety should be monitored closely, and his medications should be adjusted as necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lidocaine and amiodarone to control the patient's arrhythmia.
2. Monitor the patient's hematocrit level closely and consider transfusing blood products if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and urine output closely to prevent worsening renal function.
4. Consider starting aspirin therapy to prevent thrombotic events.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure closely and adjust his medications as necessary.
6. Continue simvastatin therapy to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia.
7. Monitor the patient's depression and anxiety closely and adjust his medications as necessary.

   pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma.
   NECK: Supple with JVP of 5 cm.
   CARDIAC: PMI displaced laterally, located in 5th intercostal space. S1
   & S2 irregular with a blowing systolic murmur heard best at apex. No
   thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were
   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or
   rhonchi.
   ABDOMEN: Soft, NT/ND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by
   palpation. No abdominial bruits.
   EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. Right thigh hematoma at cath site with borders
   demarcated in marker, no hematoma or bruit of left thigh.
   SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas.

   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, now on
   lidocaine ggt and amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min. There are two distinct morphologies of his arrythmia, likely
   one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral valve area (he
   has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Continue heparin drip, Coumadin held yesterday
   - Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID up from 50mg PO TID
   - Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit continues to drop from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution, but consider CT scan to rule out retroperitoneal
   bleed, will re-check hct at 1300
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.
   - Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
   - Continue Heparin gtt goal PTT 60-100 (per nomogram)
   - Hold Coumadin due to unknown bleeding source
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once anemia resolves
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine

Based on the patient's daily progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Medical History:**

* The patient has a history of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and sustained ventricular tachycardia episodes, resulting in multiple ICD firings.
* He has MVP and MS, and has undergone unsuccessful ablation procedures in the past.
* The patient has a history of depression and anxiety, and is currently taking Effexor, Clonazepam, and Ambien.

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is currently in the ICU due to recurrent episodes of symptomatic sustained VT.
* He was treated with lidocaine and amiodarone boluses, and his Lopressor was changed to 50mg TID.
* The patient remains anxious about his heart rhythm and is currently on a lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of NSVT and sustained VT episodes increases the risk of recurrent episodes, which can lead to cardiac arrest or sudden death.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's rate-controlled atrial fibrillation increases the risk of stroke and cardiac arrhythmias.
* Anemia: The patient's dropping hematocrit and history of bleeding complications increase the risk of anemia and potential bleeding complications.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's history of arrhythmia-induced acute renal failure and current electrolyte imbalances increase the risk of further renal dysfunction.
* Depression and anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety, combined with his current medical condition, increases the risk of depression and anxiety exacerbation.
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy increases the risk of cardiac failure and arrhythmias.

**Recommendations:**

* Continue lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID to control ventricular tachycardia.
* Increase Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID to control atrial fibrillation.
* Monitor the patient's hematocrit and consider transfusions as necessary.
* Continue heparin drip to prevent DVT and pulmonary embolism.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider adjusting medications as necessary.
* Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once the patient's anemia resolves.
* Continue Simvastatin to manage hyperlipidemia.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider adjusting medications as necessary.
* Consider starting a stress test to evaluate the patient's cardiac function and identify any potential cardiac issues.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and multiple ICD firings. He was admitted with symptoms of sustained polymorphic VT and was treated with lidocaine and amiodarone boluses. His Lopressor was changed to 50mg TID, and his ICD was evaluated and changed to an overdrive pace rate of 125.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 62 bpm (45-135 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 127/75 mmHg (89-134/85-99 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute (8-25 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 96%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* A displaced lateral PMI
* A blowing systolic murmur at the apex
* No thrills, lifts, S3, or S4
* No chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis
* Soft, non-tender abdomen
* No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272,000/μL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Ventricular tachycardia
* Anemia
* Atrial fibrillation
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
* Hyperlipidemia
* Acute renal failure

The patient's plan includes:

* Continuing heparin drip and Coumadin hold
* Increasing Metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
* Continuing lidocaine drip at 2mg/min and amiodarone 400mg TID
* Holding home verapamil
* Telemetry monitoring
* Nitro prn chest pain
* Maintaining K>4 and Mg>2
* Obtaining 12-lead EKG if VT recurs

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Continued arrhythmia and VT recurrences
* Progression of anemia and acute renal failure
* Complications of atrial fibrillation, such as stroke or thromboembolism
* Hypertensive crisis or hypotension due to changes in blood pressure
* Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure
* Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or bowel obstruction
* Infections, such as sepsis or urinary tract infections
* Cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or cardiogenic shock.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from another hospital after experiencing repeated episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and multiple ICD firings. He had an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was started on lidocaine and amiodarone. He had two distinct morphologies of his arrhythmia, likely one coming from the lateral ventricle and one from the mitral valve area. He had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and another run the next morning, which broke on its own without defibrillation. He was restarted on home coumadin and heparin was discontinued. He is currently on lidocaine and amiodarone, and his medications were adjusted to include metoprolol, aspirin, and simvastatin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular Tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and repeated episodes of VT while in the hospital suggest a high risk of further VT episodes. The patient's ICD is currently set to overdrive pace at 125 beats per minute, but this may not be sufficient to prevent further VT episodes.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate-controlled atrial fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Stopping the heparin drip today and restarting coumadin may increase the risk of thromboembolic events.
3. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit continues to drop, likely due to hemodilution. Further monitoring and potential transfusions may be necessary to manage this condition.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his urine output is being monitored. Further evaluation and management of his renal function are necessary to prevent further decline.
5. Depression/Anxiety: The patient is experiencing depression and anxiety, which may impact his overall well-being and response to medical treatment. Further evaluation and management of his mental health are necessary.
6. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: The patient has a history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which may increase his risk of VT and other cardiac complications. Further evaluation and management of his cardiomyopathy are necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue lidocaine and amiodarone to manage VT episodes.
2. Monitor the patient's EKG and vital signs closely for further VT episodes.
3. Restart coumadin and discontinue heparin drip.
4. Continue metoprolol and aspirin to manage hypertension and hyperlipidemia.
5. Monitor the patient's urine output and creatinine level to manage acute renal failure.
6. Further evaluate and manage the patient's depression and anxiety.
7. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and sustained ventricular tachycardia episodes, who was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and initiation of sotalol to control his heart rate. He was started on lidocaine and amiodarone, but continued to experience episodes of VT. An electrophysiology study (EPS) was performed, which resulted in the successful ablation of one VT focus, but not all foci, and the patient required multiple defibrillations during the procedure. He was restarted on lidocaine and amiodarone, and his medications were adjusted to include metoprolol, coumadin, and aspirin.

The patient's current medications include:

* Lidocaine IV
* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 75mg PO TID
* Coumadin 5mg daily
* Aspirin (considered for starting once anemia resolves)
* Simvastatin
* Effexor 75mg PO daily
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn for sleep
* Famotidine
* Colace, Senna, and MiraLax for bowel regimen
* Tylenol and Fentanyl prn for pain management

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hematocrit 33%
* White blood cell count 11.7 K/uL
* Platelet count 272 K/uL
* Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
* Glucose 107 mg/dL
* Calcium 9.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate 3.3 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Vital signs: temperature 36.6°C, heart rate 62 bpm, blood pressure 127/75 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 96%
* Cardiac examination: S1 and S2 irregular, with a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex
* Pulmonary examination: no wheezes, rhonchi, or crackles
* Abdominal examination: soft, non-tender, and non-distended
* Extremity examination: no edema, and pulses are 2+ in both upper and lower extremities

Potential medical complications:

* Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the recent EPS procedure increase his risk of recurrent VT episodes.
* Anemia: The patient's hematocrit is decreasing, which may be due to hemodilution or bleeding.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient has rate-controlled atrial fibrillation, which may increase his risk of stroke or thromboembolism.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, which may be due to pre-renal failure or other causes.
* Depression and anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may increase his risk of suicidal behavior or worsening of symptoms.
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may increase his risk of heart failure or arrhythmias.
* Hyperlipidemia: The patient's diagnosis of hyperlipidemia may increase his risk of coronary artery disease or other cardiovascular complications.

Recommendations:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and cardiac rhythm.
* Adjust the patient's medications as needed to control his VT episodes and other medical conditions.
* Consider starting aspirin once the patient's anemia resolves.
* Monitor the patient's urine output and creatinine level to assess for acute renal failure.
* Consider starting a stress ulcer prophylaxis medication, such as ranitidine or sucralfate.
* Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his medications as needed to control his depression and anxiety.

   Assessment and Plan
 OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA (OSA)
 VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA, SUSTAINED
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, initially
   on lidocaine ggt and amiodarone, now just on amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped [**2118-8-31**]
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Restarted on 3 mg coumadin.  D/C
ed heparin gtt.  INR 1.8 this AM, so
   will need to start heparin IV as bridge to Coumadin 5mg this AM
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID [**2118-9-1**]
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID taper to 400mg [**Hospital1 7**] after one week at
   TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct stable at 33.4
   -Haptoglobin of 251 which does not support a hemolysis
   - stool guaiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has defibrillated back into sinus
   rhythm and will be started on heparin SC with bridge to Coumadin.  Will
   change coumadin dose to 5mg today as INR was subtherapeutic at 1.8 this
   AM.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin IV-> coumadin 5mg
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   -Pt states the mask is uncomfortable but the one at home is a better
   fit. Pt was explained the benefits of using his CPAP continuously
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Hospital1 **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   -Pt is urinating well
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin/ heparin SC
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's health progress and potential medical complications:

**Summary:**

The patient, a 59-year-old male, was admitted to the ICU with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), ventricular tachycardia (VT), and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was started on amiodarone. The patient has been experiencing repeated episodes of VT, requiring multiple defibrillations during the procedure and subsequent episodes. He was also diagnosed with anemia, atrial fibrillation, hyperlipidemia, and acute renal failure.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Cardiac Complications:**
	* Recurrent VT episodes may lead to cardiac arrest or sudden cardiac death.
	* Amiodarone therapy may cause cardiac toxicity, including QT prolongation and arrhythmias.
	* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may worsen cardiac function and increase the risk of heart failure.
2. **Renal Complications:**
	* Acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
	* Pre-renal failure due to volume depletion may worsen kidney function.
3. **Anemia:**
	* Hemodilution may continue, leading to further anemia and potential bleeding complications.
4. **Atrial Fibrillation:**
	* Uncontrolled atrial fibrillation may lead to stroke or systemic embolization.
5. **Hyperlipidemia:**
	* Untreated hyperlipidemia may increase the risk of cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction and stroke.
6. **Depression/Anxiety:**
	* Untreated depression and anxiety may worsen the patient's quality of life and increase the risk of suicidal behavior.
7. **Nutritional Complications:**
	* Malnutrition may exacerbate the patient's underlying medical conditions and increase the risk of infections.

**Recommendations:**

1. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and arrhythmia episodes closely.
2. Adjust amiodarone therapy to minimize cardiac toxicity.
3. Optimize fluid management to prevent pre-renal failure.
4. Continue anemia treatment to prevent further anemia and bleeding complications.
5. Control atrial fibrillation with anticoagulation therapy and rate control medications.
6. Manage hyperlipidemia with statin therapy.
7. Provide psychological support and therapy for depression and anxiety.
8. Ensure adequate nutrition and glycemic control to prevent malnutrition and infections.

5. Infection: The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate an underlying infection. If the patient develops an infection, it may lead to further complications, including sepsis or organ failure.

   Assessment and Plan
 OBSTRUCTIVE SLEEP APNEA (OSA)
 VENTRICULAR TACHYCARDIA, SUSTAINED
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, initially
   on lidocaine ggt and amiodarone, now just on amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped [**2118-8-31**]
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Restarted on 3 mg coumadin.  D/C
ed heparin gtt.  INR 2.2 [**2118-9-1**]
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID [**2118-9-1**]
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct stable at 33.4
   -Haptoglobin of 251 which does not support a hemolysis
   - stool guiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.  Currently off as pt
   on coumadin.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin gtt off, pt on home coumadin
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   -Pt states the mask is uncomfortable but the one at home is a better
   fit. Pt was explained the benefits of using his CPAP continuously
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once anemia resolves
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   -Pt is urinating well
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine
   CODE: Full
   CONTACT: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 31**] [**Known lastname 9222**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9227**]; [**Name (NI) 815**] [**Name (NI) 9228**] (Girlfriend)

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and atrial fibrillation (AFib). He has been experiencing repeated episodes of VT, resulting in multiple ICD firings, and has undergone an unsuccessful ablation procedure. He is currently on amiodarone and metoprolol, and his heart rate is controlled. He also has a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), anemia, hyperlipidemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and acute renal failure.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.9°C (98.4°F)
* Heart rate: 52 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 91/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 96%

His physical examination is notable for a displaced apex beat, irregular S1 and S2 heart sounds, and a blowing systolic murmur at the apex. He has no chest wall deformities, scoliosis, or kyphosis.

Laboratory results include:

* Hemoglobin: 11.6 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 36.5%
* Platelet count: 272 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 21 mEq/L
* Electrolytes: normal
* Glucose: 107 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and AFib increases his risk of developing further episodes of VT, which can lead to cardiac arrest or sudden death.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of AFib increases his risk of developing further episodes of AFib, which can lead to cardiac arrest or stroke.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further complications such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased cardiac output.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further complications such as cardiovascular disease, stroke, and peripheral artery disease.
6. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias, cardiac failure, and sudden death.
7. Obstructive sleep apnea: The patient's OSA may worsen if not properly treated, leading to further complications such as sleep deprivation, daytime fatigue, and increased risk of cardiovascular events.

Recommendations:

1. Continue amiodarone and metoprolol to control the patient's heart rate and rhythm.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation closely to detect any changes in his cardiac status.
3. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely to detect any changes in his electrolyte balance.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely to detect any changes in his renal function.
5. Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once the patient's anemia resolves to reduce his risk of cardiovascular events.
6. Continue simvastatin to manage the patient's hyperlipidemia.
7. Continue metoprolol to manage the patient's hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
8. Consider referring the patient to a sleep specialist to further manage his OSA.
9. Monitor the patient's mental status closely to detect any changes in his mental health.
10. Consider referring the patient to a psychologist or psychiatrist to further manage his depression and anxiety.

ed heparin gtt.  INR 1.8 this AM, so

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital after experiencing repeated episodes of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and was diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). He has a history of non-sustained VT and has undergone an electrophysiology study (EPS) with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not all foci. He is currently on amiodarone and metoprolol for heart rhythm management.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 52 beats per minute, blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His respiratory support is minimal, with no oxygen delivery device in use.

The patient's physical examination reveals a pleasant gentleman who appears comfortable, with no signs of distress. His cardiovascular examination shows a regular rate with a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His lung examination is unremarkable, with no signs of wheezing or rhonchi.

Laboratory results show a hemoglobin of 11.6 g/dL, hematocrit of 36.5%, and platelet count of 272 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, with no evidence of coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin due to his warfarin dosing.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the presence of multiple VT foci increase the risk of recurrent VT episodes.
2. Arrhythmia: The patient's use of amiodarone and metoprolol may increase the risk of arrhythmia, particularly atrial fibrillation.
3. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin level of 11.6 g/dL may indicate anemia, which could worsen if not addressed.
4. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL may indicate acute renal failure, which could worsen if not managed promptly.
5. Depression/anxiety: The patient's use of Effexor and Clonazepam may increase the risk of depression and anxiety, which could worsen if not managed promptly.

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

1. Continue monitoring the patient's vital signs and cardiac rhythm.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen as necessary to manage his VT and arrhythmia.
3. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's anemia.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
5. Continue to manage the patient's depression and anxiety symptoms with his current medication regimen.

   .

   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped yesterday
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Restarted on 3 mg coumadin.  D/C
ed heparin gtt.  INR ***** this AM.
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID yesterday
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct stable.
   - stool guiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has rate controlled atrial
   fibrillation and is currently on a heparin drip. Heparin drip stopped
   at 10am [**8-30**] for EPS, but continued after study.  Currently off as pt
   on coumadin.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin gtt off, pt on home coumadin
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization once anemia resolves
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Month/Year (2) **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), ventricular tachycardia (VT), and atrial fibrillation (AFib). He was admitted to the ICU after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and initiation of sotalol to control his rate. The patient has a history of NSVT with sustained VT episodes and is s/p ICD placement.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, metoprolol, and coumadin. He was previously on lidocaine and heparin drips, which were stopped and restarted, respectively. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, hyperlipidemia, and acute renal failure, likely due to arrhythmia.

The patient's physical examination is stable, with no signs of distress. His vital signs are within normal limits, except for a heart rate of 52 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Arrhythmia: The patient's history of VT and AFib increases his risk of arrhythmia. The patient's current medications, including amiodarone and metoprolol, may not be sufficient to control his arrhythmia.
2. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not properly managed. The patient's stool guaiac test was negative, but further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his anemia.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not properly managed. The patient's creatinine level has decreased to 1.0 mg/dL, but further monitoring is needed to ensure that his kidney function is improving.
4. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's depression and anxiety may worsen if not properly managed. The patient is currently taking Effexor, Clonazepam, and Ambien, but further evaluation and treatment may be needed.
5. OSA: The patient's OSA may worsen if not properly managed. The patient is currently on home CPAP therapy, but further evaluation and treatment may be needed.

Based on the patient's progress note, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to ensure that his arrhythmia is properly controlled.
2. Further evaluate the patient's anemia to determine the cause and develop a plan to manage it.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's kidney function to ensure that his acute renal failure is properly managed.
4. Further evaluate and treat the patient's depression and anxiety.
5. Continue to manage the patient's OSA with home CPAP therapy and further evaluation and treatment as needed.

Summary:

The patient is a 59-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), ventricular tachycardia (VT), and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and initiation of sotalol to control his ventricular rate. He is currently on amiodarone and metoprolol to control his VT and hypertension.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 52 bpm, and blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. He has a right thigh hematoma at the catheter site, but no other signs of bleeding or trauma.

The patient's laboratory results show a hematocrit of 36.5%, with a platelet count of 272 K/uL and a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

The patient's physical examination reveals a pleasant gentleman in no acute distress, with a supple neck and no signs of jugular venous distension. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient's history of VT and the presence of multiple defibrillations during the ablation procedure increase his risk of recurrent VT.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of a heparin drip increase his risk of bleeding complications.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's history of acute renal failure and the presence of a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL increase his risk of further renal deterioration.
4. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit level of 36.5% indicates a moderate anemia, which may increase his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure of 91/45 mmHg may increase his risk of end-organ damage, such as kidney or cardiac damage.
6. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's history of hyperlipidemia and the presence of a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL increase his risk of further cardiovascular complications.
7. Depression/anxiety: The patient's history of depression and anxiety may increase his risk of suicidal ideation or behavior.

Recommendations:

1. Continue amiodarone and metoprolol to control the patient's VT and hypertension.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes in his condition.
3. Consider starting aspirin this hospitalization to reduce his risk of further cardiovascular complications.
4. Continue the patient's prophylactic anticoagulation with coumadin to reduce his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely to detect any changes in his condition.
6. Consider starting a beta-blocker to control the patient's hypertension.
7. Continue the patient's antidepressant medications to manage his depression and anxiety.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and atrial fibrillation (AF). He was transferred to the ICU after an unsuccessful ablation procedure and initiation of sotalol to control his arrhythmia.

Current medical conditions:

1. Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a history of NSVT with sustained VT episodes and is s/p ICD placement. He has two distinct morphologies of his arrhythmia, likely one coming from the lateral ventricle and one from the mitral valve area.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has defibrillated back into sinus rhythm and will be started on heparin SC with bridge to Coumadin.
3. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33, likely due to hemodilution.
4. Acute renal failure: The etiology is likely due to arrhythmia, with Cr levels increasing from 1.4 at OSH to 1.1 at admission, and then to 1.2 on 8-30.
5. Hyperlipidemia: The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of coronary artery disease.
6. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: The patient has preserved EF= 55-60% and no signs of failure.
7. Depression/Anxiety: The patient is being treated with Effexor, Clonazepam, and Ambien.

Potential medical complications:

1. Arrhythmia recurrence: The patient's VT and AF may recur, potentially leading to further episodes of cardiac arrest or stroke.
2. Renal failure progression: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not adequately managed, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, or even end-stage renal disease.
3. Bleeding risk: The patient's anticoagulation therapy with heparin and Coumadin may increase his risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
4. Thromboembolic events: The patient's anticoagulation therapy may also increase his risk of thromboembolic events, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
5. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system due to his cardiac condition and medications may increase his risk of developing infections, particularly respiratory or urinary tract infections.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and potential gastrointestinal bleeding may increase his risk of bleeding complications.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue anticoagulation therapy with heparin and Coumadin to manage the patient's AF and reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.
2. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust his fluid management and diuretic therapy as necessary to prevent further renal failure.
3. Manage the patient's arrhythmia with medications such as amiodarone and metoprolol, and consider further ablation procedures if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust his antidepressant and anxiolytic medications as necessary to manage his depression and anxiety.
5. Continue prophylactic measures to prevent DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
6. Monitor the patient's glycemic control and adjust his insulin therapy as necessary to prevent hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of his cardiac condition, anticoagulation therapy, and potential complications to ensure optimal outcomes.

   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or
   rhonchi.

   quadrants
   EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. Right thigh hematoma at cath site. Nontender, no
   fluctuation.  no hematoma or bruit of left thigh.

   Assessment and Plan
   59 yo M x-fer from CMC w/ repeated episodes of VT resulting in multiple
   ICD firings, s/p EPS with successful ablation of one VT focus, but not
   all foci requiring multiple defibrillations during procedure, initially
   on lidocaine ggt and amiodarone, now just on amiodarone.
   .
   # Ventricular tachycardia: The patient has a [**1-28**] year history of NSVT
   with Sustained Ventricular tachycardia episodes and is s/p ICD
   placement. He was transferred from CMC after an unsuccessful ablation
   ([**8-24**]) and unsuccessful initiation of sotalol to control his rate.
   Initially was on lidocaine ggt, EP wanted drip off for study, but pt
   went back into VT, so drip was restarted. [**8-30**] he received 200mg
   lidocaine at 4- 50mg boluses with rate of ggt increased from 1mg/min to
   2mg/min, currently off. There are two distinct morphologies of his
   arrythmia, likely one coming from lateral ventricle and one from mitral
   valve area (he has MVP and MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]).
   - lidocaine drip stopped [**2118-8-31**]
   - EPS [**8-30**] was performed by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] with
   successful ablation of one but not all foci, patient required
   defibrillation several times during procedure
   - Had a run of symptomatic sustained VT following the procedure and
   another run the AM of [**8-31**] which broke on its own without defibrillation
   - Went back into A fib yesterday which triggered some non-sustained
   polymorphic VT
   - INR =1.7 this AM, so will need to start heparin IV gtt as bridge to
   Coumadin 5mg.
   - Metoprolol was increased to 75mg PO TID [**2118-9-1**], Diltiazem 30mg QID
   started on [**9-2**]
   - Aggressive magnesium repletion
   - Continue amiodarone 400mg TID taper to 400mg [**Hospital1 7**] after one week at
   TID
   - Hold home verapamil
   - Telemetry
   - Nitro prn chest pain
   - Maintain K>4, Mg>2
   - Obtain 12 lead EKG if he goes back into VT
   .
   # Anemia:  Hematocrit initially dropped from 44 on admission to 33
   -Likely hemodilution.  Repeat Hct this AM is 35.
   -Haptoglobin of 251 which does not support a hemolysis
   - stool guaiac negative
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has defibrillated back into sinus
   rhythm and will be started on heparin IV gtt with bridge to Coumadin.
   Will change coumadin dose to 5mg today as INR was subtherapeutic at 1.7
   this AM.
   - Cont metoprolol at 75mg PO TID
   - heparin IV-> coumadin 5mg
   .
   #OSA- restarted on home CPAP
   -Pt states the mask is uncomfortable but the one at home is a better
   fit. Pt was explained the benefits of using his CPAP continuously
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia- The patient has hyperlipidemia but no evidence of
   coronary artery disease. He has not been on aspirin because of his
   warfarin dosing.
   - Continue Simvastatin
   .
   # Hypertropic cardiomyopathy- As per recent [**Hospital1 **], preserved EF= 55-60%
   and no signs of failure.
   - Continue Metoprolol
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure: etiology likely due to arrhythmia. Cr was 1.4 at
   OSH, 1.1 at admission, 1.2 on [**8-30**]. Urine lytes ordered, FeNa=0.6,
   indicating pre-renal failure likely [**2-28**] volume depletion.
   - ARF now resolved, Cr now down to 1
   - Monitor UOP
   -Pt is urinating well
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety:
   - Continue Effexor 75mg PO Daily (although this drug does prolong Qt
   interval)
   - Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
   - Ambien prn Sleep
   - Ativan PRN for anxiety
   .
   FEN: Cardiac Diet
   ACCESS: 2 PIV's
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with coumadin/ heparin SC
   -Pain management with Tylenol, Fentanyl prn
   -Bowel regimen with Colace, Senna, MIralax
   -Famotidine

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

* The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of ventricular tachycardia (VT) and atrial fibrillation (Afib) who was transferred from another hospital after an unsuccessful ablation procedure.
* The patient's current rhythm is atrial flutter with polymorphic VT.
* He is asymptomatic and feeling well, with no signs of heart failure or shock.
* His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 55-86 beats per minute, blood pressure of 104/65 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute.
* His laboratory results show normal hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, but slightly elevated creatinine levels, indicating potential acute renal failure.
* He has a history of anemia, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia, and is being treated for these conditions.
* He is receiving anticoagulation therapy with heparin and coumadin, and is being monitored for bleeding and thrombosis.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and atrial fibrillation
* Acute renal failure, which can progress to chronic kidney disease if left untreated
* Bleeding complications due to anticoagulation therapy
* Thrombotic complications, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism
* Hypoglycemia due to insulin therapy
* Infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections
* Respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
* Sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical condition to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is a 59-year-old male who was transferred from the Cardiac Medicine Clinic (CMC) with a history of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT) episodes. He underwent an unsuccessful ablation procedure and was started on amiodarone. The patient has been experiencing episodes of VT, including a recent episode of polymorphic VT, and has been treated with lidocaine and metoprolol.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F)
* Heart rate: 55 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 104/65 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's physical examination is notable for a pleasant gentleman in no acute distress, with a regular rate and rhythm, and a blowing systolic murmur heard best at the apex. His lungs are clear, and his abdomen is soft and nontender.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.1 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 33.4%
* Platelet count: 272,000/μL
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 17 mg/dL
* Sodium: 141 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.0 mEq/L
* Chloride: 105 mEq/L
* Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.6 mg/dL
* White blood cell count: 11.7 x 10^9/L
* Absolute neutrophil count: 9.5 x 10^9/L

The patient's current medications include:

* Amiodarone 400mg TID
* Metoprolol 75mg PO TID
* Diltiazem 30mg QID
* Simvastatin
* Coumadin 5mg
* Heparin IV gtt
* Lidocaine ggt (stopped)
* Magnesium repletion
* Nitro prn chest pain
* Effexor 75mg PO daily
* Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn sleep
* Ativan PRN for anxiety

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue amiodarone 400mg TID
* Increase metoprolol to 75mg PO TID
* Start Diltiazem 30mg QID
* Taper amiodarone to 400mg QID after one week
* Hold home verapamil
* Obtain 12-lead EKG if the patient goes back into VT
* Monitor urine output
* Continue Effexor 75mg PO daily
* Continue Clonazepam 0.5mg PO TID PRN
* Ambien prn sleep
* Ativan PRN for anxiety

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Cardiac arrhythmias, including VT and atrial fibrillation
* Acute kidney injury due to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation
* Infection, including pneumonia and urinary tract infection
* Thromboembolic events, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, I recommend continued close monitoring of his vital signs, cardiac rhythm, and laboratory results. The patient's medication regimen should be continued as directed, and the patient should be educated on the importance of adhering to his treatment plan.
